review.des:
All I can say is that this is a must go to in Chicago!!!!! What an amazing experience. At first I was worried that it was just the hip place to go to, but all the hype is 100% true. If you want to go, please reserve with a good amount of time in advance. The weekend we were in town was fully booked but we decided to take a peek. We got lucky and sat in one of those long family tables outside with other parties sitting next to us.

The experience was so fantastic that we did not even notice the people around us. We started with an order of the roasted califlower which was delicious. Then ordered the scallop and sausage summer succotash along with the  wood fired lamb ribs with a blueberry glaze. Yes, it was as amazing as it sounds. I do not eat lamb, but we devoured the plate!!!! Of course we had our side of red wine to bring everything together nicely.

The staff was friendly, the food was cooked to perfection with amazing flavors and the dessert was the cherry on top. It looked different, it tasted heavenly. For all my chocolate lovers, order the chocolate pavlova!! It will not disappoint.

We are heading to Chicago in November and already reserved a table. This time we are bringing along some friends so that they too can experience this delicious adventure! Hope you have a delightful experience like us :)

pics.caption: Babe enjoying the delicious wood fired lamb
Lucky we were able to sit outside...place was packed

review.des:
Ambiance
The Girl and the Goat is a super duper modern rustic look and feel inside.  They have an open kitchen to see all the action.  We had a seat for two so it was in those long tables where one is close to the next table.  It's easy to hear the chatter of the next door table.

Food
Wow, the food did not disappoint.  So many good dishes for a great value at such a high class restaurant like this.    

-Goat satay:  Very well cooked.  Tasted almost like lamb.
-Pig's face: reminds me of lechon kwali of the same Philippines dish. Doesn't taste like pork, can tell more with the middle.
-Beef shank: Fall off the bone, very tender very moist. Goes well with kimchi, ranch, butternut squash, and the naan.
-PB&J: Definitely peanut butter taste with some ice cream on top.  The brittle is very good.
-Birthday ice cream desert -Crunchy brittle with vanilla ice cream is delicious.

Service
I thought the customer service is pretty good.  We were able to get a birthday desert since it was my fiancee's birthday.

Wow. I have to say, I had my doubts. Over 7,000 reviews and reservations being made months in advance, could this place really be THAT good? Well, just like Hamilton, the HYPE IS REAL.

We made reservations for a Saturday night at 11:30pm two months in advance! It was the only slot available, which worked out perfectly because we went to see a show beforehand. We were seated in the dining room. The ambiance is dark and a little loud. They play a lot of groovy top 40 music.

We ordered a few cocktails, but the real star were the dishes. They recommend family style. It's a great way to try multiple things and trust me, you're going to want to try everything. The reason why is the flavor. Everything is full of unique and delicious flavors!

We started with the olive yu(zu) focaccia. The yuzu butter was brilliant and so smooth on the olive focaccia. I could eat this bread everyday. What an interesting way to use yuzu.

Next, we tried the goat empanadas. Again, the sauces on the empanadas were so flavorful. I loved the crunch of the onions over the warm, crisp empanadas. The goat meat was soft and tender.

We tried the bucatini and pork shank from the meats section of the menu. The bucatini noodles tasted freshly made and had a creamy sauce on it. We really liked this dish. The pork shank is MASSIVE. The meat falls right off the bone. It's so tender and the two sauces that come with it are perfection. I love the pickled radishes and naan that come with it as well.

We didn't save room for desserts. We were too full from the taste adventure we got to partake in.

This may be one of the best restaurants I've ever been to. The flavors were unreal and it was absolutely amazing.

Absolutely amazing. We saw a last minute reservation on Open Table for 4:30 and booked it that afternoon. By 5pm almost the entire restaurant was full. Hostesses were very friendly to me and the others I saw them seat.

The two seater tables were very tight and next to each other and tables had to be pulled out a bit for the booth person to get in and out.

Server was very knowledgeable about menu items and recommendations based on our likes. They suggest sharing everything and 4 dishes for 2 people. Our 3 filled us just fine; salad, crab cakes and pork shank. All to die for!!!

This place is incredible. I finally was able to get a reservation at 7:15 last Friday, and after one visit, it has instantly climbed to the top of my list in not only Chicago, but also nationwide. 4.5 stars on 7500 reviews speaks for itself in the Yelp universe.

You HAVE to have a reservation if you want a table here, and likely will have to make that reservation weeks in advance if you plan on coming on a weekend. Wait times exceed 2-3 hours, as this restaurant is situated on Randolph Street in the insanely popular "West Loop" neighborhood in Chicago, which is quickly becoming one of the culinary capitals of the country. They're neighbors with the notorious "Au Cheval" amongst others. From what I understand, the bar is first come, first serve, and you can order from the full menu here if you're willing to hawk seats.

Stephanie Izard has been getting a lot of press recently, and in my opinion, she deserves even more. I cannot emphasize how pleased I was  with this meal. I had done a fair amount of research on yelp beforehand, so I had a pretty good idea of the fan favorites. Dress is very casual as well, which is an added bonus.

After about a 15-minute wait, we were seated and ordered a bottle of white wine, which was reasonably priced. They also comped us some focaccia for not having our table ready when we were seated. I'm allergic to shrimp, so we steered clear of all shellfish dishes, but here are my less-than definitive rankings of everything we ordered (favorite to least):

Roasted Cauliflower
Pan Roasted Halibut
Sautéed Green Beans
Blueberry Bourbon Baba
Grilled Pork Belly
Chickpea Fritter Chaat
Ratatouille Focaccia
Skuna Bay Salmon
Braised Beef Tongue
Wood Fired Lamb Ribs

I would HIGHLY recommend you get AT LEAST everything up until the Focaccia. Seriously do not skip the cauliflower... even if you don't like vegetables. I could eat this all day. The salmon and beef tongue were pretty average in my opinion, though my friends RAVED about the salmon. The only dish I didn't care much for was the ribs, but these came second-to-last, and I was pretty full at this point. They are a bit fatty, so it really depends how you like your meat. My friend said this was his favorite dish. This was MORE than enough food for the 4 of us, and we all had arrived extremely hungry.

I know that the goat empanadas, scallops, squash blossom rangoon and crab cakes are also really popular. Gives good reason to return.

As if this place wasn't already spectacular, the service was stellar (we left well over 20%+ for tip), as they were really diligent all night. Our waiter also "sequenced" our food out, as we ordered all at once, which demonstrated the expertise / knowledgeability of the waitstaff here. There was 4 of us dining, and all said, even with the wine and dessert, this meal came out to under $70 / person, which is incredible for a meal of this caliber.

A+, would give 6 stars if I could, and you're almost certain to love, regardless of your demographic. Concurrently a great place for any kind of date, but you shouldn't feel guilty coming in with kids either. Fingers crossed that Izard + Co. will get the praise they so deserve from the folks over at Michelin next year.

Food is really good, but the place is a little bit noisy which makes difficult to have a conversation, however food wise and service they have 5 stars!

El lugar esta bonito y la comida muy rica, es un poco ruidoso lo que lo hace difícil para tener una conversación pero la comida, bebidas y servicio son excelentes

Walked in with no reservation and didn't want to wait for a table so we sat at the bar (just me and one other person). We ate very comfortably at the bar but if you do want a table, make a reservation. The bar tender/server was extremely helpful! Great service! We had the such a fun-gi bread, sautéed green beans, seared scallops, and pan roasted arctic char. The combination of ingredients was surprising and amazing. Also loved how the place was decorated, comfortable setting

Oh my gosh, what a wonderful meal! My husband and I finally used a gift card we had received for this restaurant and it was such an enjoyable experience. The server was so great, really helped with giving us recommendations. Everything is shared, they recommend 2-3 plates per person. We decided on bread, green beans, salmon, oven roasted pig face, confit goat belly, and caramel corn malt balls to top it all off. Seriously, everything I ate was delicious. I think my favorites were the salmon, it definitely was way better than it is described on the menu, and the confit goat belly, which was rich and decadent. I left extremely full and extremely satisfied. Highly recommend!

Let's be serious, what can I really add here? This place is AMAZING. One of the star restaurants of Chicago, yet unassuming and inviting without a hint of snobbery. The chef shows off her skill with this restaurant - each dish is carefully curated to be packed with great flavors, unique enough to leave you wondering how they made it. We came here to celebrate a special occasion and couldn't decide what to order but our waiter was super helpful at recommending a good combo and amount of food.

Food: Let's just say it now, first things first - you HAVE to get the green beans. Schwaa? You are going to a top restaurant to get.. green beans? For real, I have never had green beans that good - I am still dreaming of the sauce and presentation. We also had the beets which were great, the soft shell crab (to die for), the pork shank (to die for) and a few cocktails (loved "It's always sunny in oaxaca" - so good, just sweet enough but not too sweet, complex taste with a bit of spice on the rim!).

Bottom line, one of the best restaurants and dining experiences of my life - would highly recommend you come here! We made reservations waaaay in advance (weeks) but it seems like you can walk in on non-peak days/times and get a spot. You HAVE to check this place out!!! PS the day we went, our waiter said the chef was in the line cooking. How cool is that!!??!

My D.C. friend texted me earlier as his plan had changed and he would not make it to Chicago after all, leaving me alone to dine on a Sunday evening. Perhaps I'm not as emotional as I used to be, or perhaps I am too sick to care, either or I was not offended, I was alone and I had my eyes set on this wildly popular restaurant. Only 0.8 mile away from my hotel, I walked faster than I thought and almost missed it. I went to the bar area and got a single seat as I was dining alone and the restaurant was booked, as per usual. When you have 7000 plus reviews and still get a 4.5 stars you wonder what is the appeal, so it's really the curiosity that led me here.

I had limited appetite so I went for a goat belly and poke, and duck tongue because I actually have eaten duck tongue before and liked it. Sure enough, both dishes were pleasant and small portioned and perfect for a table for one. I also got some ice tea to chase down my salty, highly processed, yet delicious food.

I understand just about anyone who has been to Chicago more than once or twice has been here before, but until recently I rarely come here and I don't know the food scene.

So when I got home and told my fellow traveler friends, they all said, "Oh yes, it's not a Michelin but it's so good, I've been there." It led me to believe that I'm really the last person in the know about Chicago's eats, but at least now I have checked off one restaurant that everyone knows about. If I'm right about this, I'll be back here in September for another meeting after D.C.

On that topic, I have not written back to my D.C. friend, who probably thinks I'm pissed at him. I'm not, I just got busy. I should probably tell him that I had gone here, I bet he's eaten here too, along with the rest of his fellow ex white house staffers under the Obama administration, along with at least half of the entire Yelp population. It's that good.

I will get fat!

Food is so good, you can't stop even if you are stuffed! From beginning to the end everything was exceptional, except the service. We wanted to try drinks of the menu to try everything and mine was fine but wife's drink was a bit to sweet. But we didn't complain, the server asked how are the drinks and wife replied "it's okay" and the server had an attitude for the rest of the night. But we overlooked that because food was really good. All and all we want to go back and try somethings that we didn't the first time and give it another go. I highly recommend the lamb chops as the slide right off the bone with no effort.

I've been waiting years to get back to Chicago to try out this gem touted by my friend Anthony B. And tonight was the night!
We sat at the bar (first come first served). You can also reserve a table but when I called 3 weeks prior, they had already been fully booked for a Sunday night!
The room was filled with the younger set: people aged 25 and up to 60s. Dress was casual due to the millennial crowd but not pretentious.
The bartender was great. We didn't order drinks but he gave us suggestions and and recommendations like we were ordering top shelf booze! Great staff everywhere! All of them were so incredibly helpful!

Course #1:  Kohlarabi salad with fresh fennel,  toasted almonds, roasted shiitake mushrooms, Dutch beemster and pears!  A unique pairing of flavors both sweet, savory and with a gentle crispness.

Course #2: Roasted Lamb ribs in blueberry tamarind glaze with fresh scallions! It's meat candy at its finest!!  After your first bite you will want a huge plate of this stuff!

Course #3: Wood grilled broccoli with melted Smokey Bleu Cheese and spiced crisped rice! Smokey deliciousness! Who would have thought broccoli could be healthy AND yummy!!

Course #4: Goat Belly Confit with bourbon butter, crab & lobster with fresh fennel!  I have to admit that I wasn't sure you could pair surf and turf like this, but OMG it was fabulous! Sir, I'll take ten more of these to go!

Course #5: Seared Diver Scallops with wild maitake & wood ear mushrooms in an oyster sauce brodo with a squash brandade! Again, a culinary masterpiece!

I always like to have a sweet finish. But there were two desserts I had to do and I figured I'd let them each duke it out for the honor of being number one!  It was a tie:

Dessert #1:
Sponge cake with a gooseberry shortbread crumble, honey mousse, whipped cream and gastriqué!

Dessert #2:
Homemade Malted vanilla ice cream with caramel corn and crispy chocolate shell!

OMG fantastic!  I just died and went to a gastronomical heaven!!

You must go at least once and look for Elaine, the Girl with the Star Wars tattoos.

Listen, I just had the greatest night of my life at Girl & the Goat. We flew in from SF and had a terrible first foodie experience the night before. With empty stomachs we were hopeful this place would meet our expectations . It exceeded them by leaps and bounds.

We had 14 dishes, 1 of them so nice we had to have it twice. Sounds like a lot, but it's meant for sharing and there were four of us. My husband and I, my broke college foodie daughter, and my young pre-teen baby foodie. They recommend 8 dishes or so for 4 people but everything was so good we just kept going!  

From beginning to end, the entire staff was welcoming and the service was impeccable. It was beautiful and busy in there, but you would never know it because the service was so outstanding. Our waitress Elaine was very sweet, knowledgeable, & had great suggestions. From the drinks to the dishes she thought we would like and even some off menu suggestions, she was killing it.
I'm definitely not a professional reviewer, I just know how this place made me feel so if I don't describe the dish adequately, sorry!
All of the dishes were great but the stand outs for us were the hamachi(refreshing and light and flavorful AF), the lamb ribs(falling off the bone and we ordered it twice), the string beans, goat carpaccio(It was beautifully presented and it was tasty), Branzino in spicy shrimp sauce(so perfectly made, I could've eaten this by myself) confit goat belly(lobster shrimp and goat-oh my! but it works! The bourbon butter was very nice. ) octopus on pepita mole is so good...I mean I guess what I'm saying is, it's worth it. It really is.

Gluten free bread that is actually delicious. I'm not gluten free, my hubby is, and usually I have to sit there all "Yeah, this is umm, good." But I actually meant it this time. If I wasn't told it was GF I would've never guessed.

This place is probably on all the must-eat/try restaurants in Chicago and it definitely lives up to the hype. If you weren't keen enough to make a reservation two months in advance, you might be lucky to snap a seat in their waiting area where you can order from the full menu without having to wait for 2 hours to be seated.

Between 2 people we shared 5 plates and everything tasted incredible. The ponzu oysters, rock shrimp, and cauliflower are must try's but I think just about anything from the menu would be good.

review.des:
So much has been written about how great this place is and I get it.  I can understand the cult-like following and applaud the restaurant's success.  In my opinion, though, that success is due mainly to the staff.  There is zero pretension in the place!  It gives off the feel of the local family restaurant.  It's first-rate food, but world-class people.

Thanks for making us feel welcome.

Update: 10/27/18

Back for another visit to "The Girl and Goat", and happy to say this experience was on par with our first. Had reservation for 6:30pm on a Saturday night (very busy) and was seated by 6:28pm. The staff was dressed in Harry Potter theme for Halloween which was funny.

We ordered the following on this go around:

Smoked Apple Pirogies
Wood fired Lamb Ribs
Duck Tongues
Wood Oven Roasted Pig Face
Goat Neck
Chocolate Pavlova Says-a-Me! (Dessert)
Sticky Tasty Crunchy Toffee Yummy Cake (Dessert)
All Nighter (Cocktail)
Talkin About Chai-Town (Cocktail)
Rory McIlroy (Cocktail)

Everything was top notch just like our last visit. We purposely tried new things this go around, since each item is always so good. The exception being the Roasted Pig Face... hard to not get that one again.

Favorites had to be the Lamb Ribs (one of the best things I've had in my life) and the Goat Neck (more food than other entrees... this was a special so probably not always available).

As usual you get through a couple small plates together and think -- "Man this is good but will it fill me up?" Then by the end you are totally stuffed.  

We definitely spent more this time ($36 on just cocktails).  The All Nighter is good but wow is it strong. Probably why they give you half a glass worth lol.

We will be back. Hard to beat this place.

Oh my goodness - one of the best restaurants we visited while in Chicago. We weren't able to get a reservation so we walked in at 5 pm (30 minutes after they opened) and were able to snag a table right away at the bar.

I started off with a puttin on the spritz cocktail, which was so refreshing and hubby had a local ipa. We got the goat Empanadas and omg so flavorful! They were served with a blueberry pick which was so unexpected but so amazing at the same time. Then we had the soft shell crab cakes which had blackberries and a soy glaze. Again, so unexpected but the flavors pair so well with each other. Next had the cauliflower and the mint was good in every bite! Last, we had the pork bucatini. A bit salt but great nonetheless.

Such. Great. Food.

4.5 stars for being inventive here. Hip ambience at this top chef restaurant. The lighting was a bit too dark for me.

I would recommend getting half portions whenever possible (eg. ravioli, cauliflower, shishito pepper) to try the maximum amount of dishes here.

MUST HAVE:
Duck Tongues with tuna and black bean poke, crispy wontons, piri piri - this dish was phenomenal. Never thought that fried duck tongue would go with tuna but it does! Great balanced of flavors and textures. Don't get scared of duck tongues which were deep fried and little bites mixed into the entire dish.

SOLID:
Roasted Cauliflower with pickled peppers, pine nuts, mint - the cauliflower is a bit over cooked but really liked the pickled spicy pepper here, which saved the dish. They doused it in parmagiano cheese (which wasn't indicated on the menu). I would have preferred it without it. They should have indicated it on the menu so people can opt out.

Escargot Ravioli - bacon tamarind sauce, escarole and celery, crispy & carmelized onions. Interesting dish. Liked the caramelized onion in this dish. The sauce was a bit too salty.

SKIP:
Pan Fried Shishito Peppers - parmesan, sesame, miso. This dish was trying to be inventive but felt short on the mix. The shishito peppers were just way too hot (1 out of 3/4 were spicy). The Parmesan creamy crust was an interesting test but just didn't go with the crunchy spiky shishito.

pics.caption: Grilled cauliflower - ask for the cheese on the side. Pretty good.
Nice ambience even though it was a bit darker than what I prefer.
Duck tongue with tuna poke - phenomenal

review.des:
With the amount of reviews this restaurant has I was really hoping it would live up to the hype which it did.  Most of the dishes here were excellent, if i had to put the them in order of my favorite to least it'd go something like this.

1. lamb ribs
2. soft shell crab
3. kohlrabi salad
4. wood oven roasted pig face (its like a breakfast plate)
5. chocolate pavlova
6. ratatouille focaccia
7. pork belly
8. sweet onion brioche
9. roasted beets
10. hamachi crudo
11. roasted cauliflower

The service here is pretty good, some of my party would disagree, but the server seemed fine to me.  If you'd like to try a refreshing cocktail try the "puttin' on the spritz", it's fruity and tangy.   One item that looked awesome that we didn't order was the pork shank, we saw many of those come off the kitchen line.   We came here with a big group so we all got to try a bunch of things (9 people) which i'd also recommend doing.  
 If you're coming from out of town then I'd suggest making reservations far in advance.  For our party of 9 we had to make reso's 2 months in advance and we could only get 5pm on a Friday.

This restaurant definitely lives up to its amazing reviews. I was in Chicago for a few days and was told this place was a must. It's based on ordering small plates -- the waitress recommended 3-4 for two people eating. The seared scallops with the summer sausage succotash were divine. The best thing I ate however was the pork shank with naan, peach slices, and two amazing sauces. It was my birthday and on top of the dessert we ordered, they brought me another delicious little treat as well. This place is perfect if you are looking to spend a bit more money on food. I didn't even mind though because it was one of the best food experiences I've ever encountered. Our waitress was super friendly and the rest of the staff were super attentive and continuously made sure we had everything we needed. I'll be dreaming of this food for years!

When a friend of mine mentioned that the Girl & the Goat was one of the best meals they've ever had in their life, I knew I had to make a trip out during my Chicago vacation. The universe must have been on my side the day I tried getting reservations because after a few minutes, I was able to snag a 7:30 dinner on my first night. (FYI: the restaurant will call you 2 days before your reservation to confirm.) When we arrived, the restaurant was completely packed (and it was a Wednesday night)!  The G&G definitely emits an overall vibey/classy/cool/ comfortable feel. I like that people dressed up but it's lowkey enough to wear jeans.

Okay, so on to the food! Our server (who was very nice and accommodating) recommended 5 plates for a party of 2. We ordered: 1) the sesame grape sourdough with BLACK SESAME BUTTER *yum!!*  2) goat empanadas 3) braised beef tongue 4)shishito peppers 5) roasted pig face.
I was completely blown away with the flavors & the execution of the dishes! The g&g is probably one of tastiest dining experiences i have ever had!

My only pit of the evening was the Carmel corn and malt balls dessert. It was extremely salty! My boyfriend and i couldn't finish it because the salt was just too overpowering. :(

Coming from New York City, I have to say this was one of the best meals I've had in 2018 so far. I had reservations for 2 on Sunday 9pm and the restaurant was packed. It was spacious, dark and loud. The service was fantastic from the moment I stepped in.

The waiter suggested 6-7 plates to share between 2 people. Unless you're starving I'd say 3-4 plates is more than enough!

We ordered:
- Goat empanadas: Good! The pico and cheese was an interesting twist giving it a burst of flavor. I only wished the portion was bigger.

- Confit goat belly: My favorite of the night! The confit was PERFECT! Crispy and super fatty melttt in your mouth delicious. The crab and lobster were soaked in this addictive buttery sauce. I almost licked the plate clean.

- Pork shank: Great! The pork shank was huge, crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. It came with a creamy buttermilk dressing and kimchi sauce that wasn't too overpowering. I LOVED the warm buttery naan. I felt that the pork itself wasn't that special. It needed the side condiments.

- Lemon make you happy: I was stuffed by the time I got to dessert. The lemon cake came warm. Very good but I thought the cake was way too sweet.

- Bubba watson cocktail: This was delicious but sadly weak with the alcohol. I had the rest of my meal with red wine.

Chef Stephanie Izard did an incredible job with the menu. She took flavors from different cultures all over the world. The combination with the ingredients paired perfectly! Such a memorable dinner. I highly recommend making reservations in advance. By the time I left around 11pm, there were still people waiting to be seated!

I'd say this place is a bit too hyped and I debated between 3 or 4 stars. Gave it 4 stars since I only tried it once and maybe I ordered too much/got full of the first items considering I dined alone here.

I ordered the chickpea fritters, pig face, and these dumpling things. I thought the fritters were good but nothing to write home about. I found the pig face too salty / too heavy for me, but this was also one of the dishes that came out last. The dumplings were also good but I thought the chickpea fritters were more interesting.

I'd consider trying this place again with a larger party so I can try more items. The cocktails were fine, but considering I had just come from The Aviary, it's hard for any cocktail to measure up.

Echoing a lot of what I've read about this place.  Was lucky to get a reservation from a friend.  Service was fantastic.  The food was great, especially the goat empenadas.

Cocktails were also very good, we were seating right next to the famous painting.

Despite my initial skepticism, Girl & the Goat is well deserving of its 4.5 star rating. I'm always suspicious of restaurants that are universally hyped. And Girl & the Goat falls squarely in that bucket. There wasn't a single person who I told about my upcoming trip to the restaurant who didn't "ooh" and "aah" about it. Which made me eye roll a bit.

Anywho, it turns out that Girl & the Goat is worthy of the hype. Most of the dishes we ordered were excellent, including the scallops, octopus and hamachi crudo. Other dishes were really good, although I'll probably try other things next time I'm there (e.g., the chickpea fritters, oysters and "breads"). I was really looking forward to trying to goat empanadas, but I was so stuffed by the time they arrived that I could only muster one bite, and I feel like I can't fairly judge them based on that bite.

Food aside, I was also really impressed with the staff. In my experience, the staff at trendy restaurants is often pretentious and annoying. But here, everyone from the hosts to the servers to the busers were friendly, respectful and seemed genuinely welcoming (shout out to my man Einstein, in particular). For me, this actually elevated the experience to a solid 5 stars.

Might be my favorite restaurant in Chicago.

Interior - Decorative, classy, and fun.

Service - Good. Dishes are timed on point to make sure you enjoy each item sufficiently before the next dish is delivered so you aren't swamped with 3 dishes at the same time all out of order.

Roasted cauliflower (pickled peppers, pine nuts, mint) - There is cheese. Delicious, salted, savory, soft, and tastes like home.

Escargot Ravioli (bacon tamarind sauce, escarole & celery, crispy onions) - Couldn't taste the escargot. Resembled more like flattened dumplings in some broth. Loved it.

Pan roasted halibut (marcona almond butter, white asparagus . blueberry nuoc cham, beech mushroom) - Fish sauce!! It was truly delicious and honored the Vietnamese fish sauce taste without watering it down. Must order.

Crisp braised pork shank (buttermilk dressing, grilled spring onion & radish kimch, naan) - Pork falls off the bone. Delicious, savory, soft. Naan is decent but the pork is so good without it.

Lemon make you happy (lemon​ pound cake, sorrel ice cream, almond crunch, cheesecake sauce) - My husband hates lemon and pound cake but he ate it all. Must order.

The Jam (Old Forester Bourbon, strawberry shrub, saison) - The perfect refreshing summer strawberry drink.
